messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Great Koshirae
messages.msgSnippet: Thanks Gordon, for both responses. They are nice looking papers, I like the use of the Mon. Just an aesthetic point of view. Rich ... From: Gordon Robson To:
messages.messageBody:
Thanks Gordon, for both responses. They are nice looking papers, I like the use of the Mon. Just an aesthetic point of view.

Rich

From: Gordon Robson
To: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com

Oh, the papers are from Shibata's shop in the Ginza.

G

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Great Koshirae
messages.msgSnippet: For those who haven t seen the book, the best detail online from the Ban Dainagon I ve found so far is here:
messages.messageBody:
For those who haven't seen the book, the best detail online from the Ban Dainagon I've found so far is here:

http://www.kyohaku.go.jp/gakuso/gakuso02/gs2a28ie.htm

Look at the fellow in the upper left hand corner. He is carrying an uchigatana with a tsuba, however it's rather difficult to say whether it might be made of iron, yamagane or leather.

Gordon - do you have any sort of image of the nagamaki tsuba? Is it a plain iron plate without sukashi?

Jim



Hi Richard,

The fuchi-kashira are MIno in style. Can't tell much about the menuki or the
tsuba, which appears to be iron. Kozuka is also difficult to tell much
about. Unfortunately, when my daughter was home the last time with her
boyfriend, they switched my internet connnection to Opera, which only reads
English, so I can't read the Japanese text.
On a slightly different note getting back to the use of Ko-Tosho and
Ko-Katchushi tsuba, I had mentioned Sasano's ideas about this. This morning
I took another look at his book Tosogu no Kigen or Origins of Sword Fittings
(actually, Katana Fittings). One of the illustrations he cites is the Ban
Daiagon scroll, which shows an elderly foot solider with an uchigatana that
has a tsuba. This scroll dates to the late Heian period. There are other
warriors with shorter blades -- koshigatana? -- that are without tsuba.
There is also a plain round iron tsuba that would be called a Ko-Tosho that
was mounted on a nagamaki. We know this because the seppa were rusted to the
tsuba and they are large and round of the type that would be for a nagamaki
handle. The tsuba is very large at 9.3 cent. across. Anyway, just thought I
would share this.

Gordon

[Non-text portions of this message have been removed]

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Great Koshirae
messages.msgSnippet: Yeah, except that is my wife s family mon as well as the most popular mon for sushi restaurants in Tokyo. Don t ask me why. G ... From: Richard Turner
messages.messageBody:
Yeah, except that is my wife's family mon as well as the most popular mon
for sushi restaurants in Tokyo. Don't ask me why.

G
----------
From: "Richard Turner" <ikkanshi@...>
To: <nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com>
Subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Great Koshirae
Date: Tue, 6 May 2003 09:31:02 +0800


Thanks Gordon, for both responses. They are nice looking papers, I like the
use of the Mon. Just an aesthetic point of view.

Rich

G

To: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com
Subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Great Koshirae
Date: Mon, 05 May 2003 10:57:46 +0900


Hi Richard,

The fuchi-kashira are MIno in style. Can't tell much about the menuki or the
tsuba, which appears to be iron. Kozuka is also difficult to tell much
about. Unfortunately, when my daughter was home the last time with her
boyfriend, they switched my internet connnection to Opera, which only reads
English, so I can't read the Japanese text.
On a slightly different note getting back to the use of Ko-Tosho and
Ko-Katchushi tsuba, I had mentioned Sasano's ideas about this. This morning
I took another look at his book Tosogu no Kigen or Origins of Sword Fittings
(actually, Katana Fittings). One of the illustrations he cites is the Ban
Daiagon scroll, which shows an elderly foot solider with an uchigatana that
has a tsuba. This scroll dates to the late Heian period. There are other
warriors with shorter blades -- koshigatana? -- that are without tsuba.
There is also a plain round iron tsuba that would be called a Ko-Tosho that
was mounted on a nagamaki. We know this because the seppa were rusted to the
tsuba and they are large and round of the type that would be for a nagamaki

would share this.

Gordon
----------
From: "Richard Turner" <ikkanshi@...>
To: <nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com>
Subject: [nihontostudy] Great Koshirae
Date: Sun, 4 May 2003 20:27:19 +0800


Hi all, this site was bought to my attention and I found this Wak. Lovely
little piece but I was particularly struck by the koshirae. I am guessing
Goto, I was discussing this with Barry Thomas and his guess was Mino Goto.
Maybe Jim G could shed some light on it.

I was also curious about the papers, would they be Seikeido's own kantei
papers ?.

http://www.seikeido.com/seikeido/1kanezumi.htm
<http://www.seikeido.com/seikeido/1kanezumi.htm>
<http://www.seikeido.com/seikeido/1kanezumi.htm
<http://www.seikeido.com/seikeido/1kanezumi.htm> >

The have some excellent tsuba and some wonderful swords. Bob R, have you
been here ?, I would guess so.

Rich T

fittings. It says that the tsuba is ko-Kinko.
Jim

little piece but I was particularly struck by the koshirae. I am guessing
Goto, I was discussing this with Barry Thomas and his guess was Mino Goto.
Maybe Jim G could shed some light on it.

I was also curious about the papers, would they be Seikeido's own kantei
papers ?.

http://www.seikeido.com/seikeido/1kanezumi.htm
<http://www.seikeido.com/seikeido/1kanezumi.htm>

The have some excellent tsuba and some wonderful swords. Bob R, have you
been here ?, I would guess so.

Rich T

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Great Koshirae
messages.msgSnippet: Hi Richard, The fuchi-kashira are MIno in style. Can t tell much about the menuki or the tsuba, which appears to be iron. Kozuka is also difficult to tell much
messages.messageBody:
Hi Richard,

The fuchi-kashira are MIno in style. Can't tell much about the menuki or the
tsuba, which appears to be iron. Kozuka is also difficult to tell much
about. Unfortunately, when my daughter was home the last time with her
boyfriend, they switched my internet connnection to Opera, which only reads
English, so I can't read the Japanese text.
On a slightly different note getting back to the use of Ko-Tosho and
Ko-Katchushi tsuba, I had mentioned Sasano's ideas about this. This morning
I took another look at his book Tosogu no Kigen or Origins of Sword Fittings
(actually, Katana Fittings). One of the illustrations he cites is the Ban
Daiagon scroll, which shows an elderly foot solider with an uchigatana that
has a tsuba. This scroll dates to the late Heian period. There are other
warriors with shorter blades -- koshigatana? -- that are without tsuba.
There is also a plain round iron tsuba that would be called a Ko-Tosho that
was mounted on a nagamaki. We know this because the seppa were rusted to the
tsuba and they are large and round of the type that would be for a nagamaki
handle. The tsuba is very large at 9.3 cent. across. Anyway, just thought I
would share this.

Gordon
----------

messages.msgSnippet: I have Japanese & Chines fonts turned on in Explorer, but I do not see the kanji or katagana or whatever on this web page.  If it works for you, I d be curious

I have Japanese & Chines fonts turned on in Explorer, but I do not see the kanji or katagana or whatever on this web page. If it works for you, I'd be curious to know what else you've done to your Explorer.
----- Original Message -----
From: Jim Gilbert
To: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com
Sent: Sunday, May 04, 2003 7:59 AM
Subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Great Koshirae


Richard,
The fuchigashira are described in the text as mid Edo period Mino kinko, which is a safe call. They look quite nice. I can't see much of the other fittings. It says that the tsuba is ko-Kinko.
Jim

Hi all, this site was bought to my attention and I found this Wak. Lovely little piece but I was particularly struck by the koshirae. I am guessing Goto, I was discussing this with Barry Thomas and his guess was Mino Goto. Maybe Jim G could shed some light on it.

I was also curious about the papers, would they be Seikeido's own kantei papers ?.

http://www.seikeido.com/seikeido/1kanezumi.htm

The have some excellent tsuba and some wonderful swords. Bob R, have you been here ?, I would guess so.

Rich T
